'''''Deus Ex''''' is a 2000 [[action role-playing game|action role-playing]] [[video game]] developed by [[Ion Storm]] and published by [[Eidos Interactive]]. Set in a [[cyberpunk]]-themed [[dystopia]]n world in the year 2052, the story follows [[JC Denton]], an agent of the fictional agency United Nations Anti-Terrorist Coalition (UNATCO), who is given superhuman abilities by [[Nanotechnology in fiction|nanotechnology]], as he sets out to combat hostile forces in a world ravaged by inequality and a deadly plague. His missions entangle him in a conspiracy that brings him into conflict with the [[Triad (organized crime)|Triads]], [[Majestic 12]], and the [[Illuminati]].
''Deus Ex''{{'}}s gameplay combines elements of the [[first-person shooter]] with [[stealth game|stealth]] elements, [[adventure game|adventure]], and [[role-playing video game|role-playing]] genres, allowing for its tasks and missions to be completed in a variety of ways, that in turn lead to differing outcomes. Presented from the [[first-person (gaming)|first-person]] perspective, the player can customize Denton's various abilities such as weapon skills or lockpicking, increasing his effectiveness in these areas; this opens up different avenues of exploration and methods of interacting with or manipulating other characters. The player can complete side missions away from the primary storyline by moving freely around the available areas, which can reward the player with experience points to upgrade abilities and alternative ways to tackle main missions.
The game was released for [[Microsoft Windows]] on June 2000, with a [[Classic Mac OS|Mac OS]] port following the next month. A modified version of the game was released for the [[PlayStation 2]] in 2002. In the years following its release, ''Deus Ex'' has received additional improvements and content from its fan community.
The game received critical acclaim, including repeatedly being named "Best PC Game of All Time" in ''[[PC Gamer]]''{{'}}s "Top 100 PC Games" in 2011 and a poll carried out by the UK gaming magazine ''[[PC Zone]]''. It received several Game of the Year awards, drawing praise for its pioneering designs in player choice and multiple narrative paths. It has sold more than 1 million copies, as of April 23, 2009. The game led to a [[Deus Ex|series]], which includes the sequel ''[[Deus Ex: Invisible War]]'' (2003), and three prequels: ''[[Deus Ex: Human Revolution]]'' (2011), ''[[Deus Ex: The Fall]]'' (2013), and ''[[Deus Ex: Mankind Divided]]'' (2016).
== Gameplay == ''Deus Ex'' incorporates elements from four [[video game genre]]s: [[role-playing video game|role-playing]], [[first-person shooter]], [[adventure game|adventure]], and "[[immersive sim]]ulation," the last of which being a game where "nothing reminds you that you're just playing a game."<ref name="gamasutra">{{cite web |url=http://www.gamasutra.com/view/feature/3114/postmortem_ion_storms_deus_ex.php |last=Spector |first=Warren |title=Postmortem: Ion Storm's ''Deus Ex'' |date=2000-12-06 |work=[[Gamasutra]] |accessdate=July 24, 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080227075340/http://www.gamasutra.com/view/feature/3114/postmortem_ion_storms_deus_ex.php |archive-date=February 27, 2008 |url-status=live |df=mdy-all }}</ref> For example, the game uses a [[Point of view (literature)#Other types and uses|first-person]] camera during gameplay and includes exploration and character interaction as primary features.<ref name="gamasutra" />
The player assumes the role of JC Denton, a [[Nanotechnology in fiction|nanotech]]-augmented operative of the [[United Nations]] Anti-Terrorist Coalition (UNATCO).<ref name="dxmanual">''Deus Ex'' game manual</ref> This nanotechnology is a central gameplay mechanism and allows players to perform [[superhuman]] feats.
=== Role-playing elements === As the player accomplishes objectives, the [[player character]] is rewarded with "skill points." Skill points are used to enhance a character's abilities in eleven different areas, and were designed to provide players with a way to customize their characters;<ref name="gamasutra" /> a player might create a combat-focused character by increasing proficiency with pistols or rifles, while a more furtive character can be created by focusing on lock picking and computer hacking abilities. There are four different levels of proficiency in each skill, with the skill point cost increasing for each successive level.<ref name="kierongillen">{{cite web |first=Kieron |last=Gillen |authorlink=Kieron Gillen |year=2005 |title=Kieron Gillen's Workblog |url=http://gillen.cream.org/wordpress_html/assorted-essays/deus-ex/ |accessdate=October 13, 2006 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120708063924/http://gillen.cream.org/wordpress_html/assorted-essays/deus-ex/ |archive-date=July 8, 2012 |url-status=dead |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref name="eurogamer">{{cite web |date=2000-08-04 |url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/warrens2 |title=Warren Spector of Ion Storm (Part Two) |work=[[Eurogamer]] |accessdate=March 27, 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090213004300/http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/warrens2 |archive-date=February 13, 2009 |url-status=live |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
Weapons may be customized through "weapon modifications," which can be found or purchased throughout the game. The player might add [[Telescopic sight|scopes]], [[Suppressor|silencers]], or [[laser sight]]s; increase the weapon's [[range of a projectile|range]], [[accuracy]], or [[magazine (firearm)|magazine]] size; or decrease its [[recoil]] and reload time; as appropriate to the weapon type.
Players are further encouraged to customize their characters through nano-augmentations—[[cybernetic]] devices that grant characters superhuman powers. While the game contains eighteen different nano-augmentations, the player can install a maximum of nine, as each must be used on a certain part of the body: one in the arms, legs, eyes, and head; two underneath the skin; and three in the torso.<ref>{{cite news|title=Deus Ex @ GameBanshee|url=http://www.gamebanshee.com/deusex/augmentations.php|accessdate=2007-11-09|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071224153307/http://www.gamebanshee.com/deusex/augmentations.php|archive-date=2007-12-24|url-status=live}}</ref> This forces the player to choose carefully between the benefits offered by each augmentation. For example, the arm augmentation requires the player to decide between boosting their character's skill in hand-to-hand combat or his ability to lift heavy objects.
Interaction with [[non-player character]]s (NPCs) was a significant design focus.<ref name="gamasutra" /> When the player interacts with a non-player character, the game will enter a [[cutscene]]-like conversation mode where the player advances the conversation by selecting from a list of dialogue options. The player's choices often have a substantial effect on both gameplay and plot, as non-player characters will react in different ways depending on the selected answer (e.g., rudeness makes them less likely to assist the player).
=== Combat elements === ''Deus Ex'' features combat similar to first-person shooters, with [[real time (media)|real-time]] action, a first-person perspective, and reflex-based gameplay.<ref name="gamasutra" /> As the player will often encounter enemies in groups, combat often tends toward a tactical approach, including the use of cover, strafing, and "[[Hit-and-run tactics|hit-and-run]]." A ''[[USA Today]]'' reviewer found, "At the easiest difficulty setting, your character is puréed again and again by an onslaught of human and robotic terrorists until you learn the value of stealth."<ref>{{cite news|last=Berman |first=A.S. |title=''Deus Ex'': Breathing new life into a tired genre |newspaper=USA Today |date=2000-08-10 |url=http://www.cincinnati.com/freetime/games/reviews/deusex.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070621233333/http://www.cincinnati.com/freetime/games/reviews/deusex.html |archivedate=2007-06-21 |accessdate=2007-07-21 |url-status=live }}</ref> However, through the game's role-playing systems, it is possible to develop a character's skills and augmentations to create a [[tank (computer gaming)|tank]]-like combat specialist with the ability to deal and absorb large amounts of damage.{{citation needed|date=November 2018}} Non-player characters will praise or criticize the main character depending on the use of force, incorporating a moral element into the gameplay.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Thompson |first=Adam J. |title=Morality Play – Creating Ethics in Video Games |date=2003-12-18 |url=http://www.adamjthompson.com/thought/CreatingEthics.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927011354/http://www.adamjthompson.com/thought/CreatingEthics.html |archivedate=2007-09-27 |accessdate=2007-08-15 |url-status=live }}</ref>
''Deus Ex'' features a [[HUD (computer gaming)|head-up display]] crosshair, whose size dynamically shows where shots will fall based on movement, aim, and the weapon in use; the reticle expands while the player is moving or shifting their aim, and slowly shrinks to its original size while no actions are taken.<ref name="dxmanual" /> How quickly the reticle shrinks depends on the character's proficiency with the equipped weapon the number of accuracy modifications added to the weapon, and the level of the "Targeting" nano-augmentation.
''Deus Ex'' features twenty-four weapons, ranging from [[crowbar (tool)|crowbars]], [[electroshock weapon]]s, and riot [[Club (weapon)|baton]], to [[laser guidance|laser-guided]] [[anti-tank]] [[rocket]]s and [[assault rifle]]s;<ref name="dxmanual" /> both lethal and [[non-lethal weapon]]s are available. The player can also make use of several weapons of opportunity, such as [[fire extinguisher]]s.
=== Player choice === [[File:How to pass obstacles in Deus Ex.jpg|thumb|left|Players are given multiple ways to traverse obstacles, from lockpicking to armed combat.]]
Gameplay in ''Deus Ex'' emphasizes player choice. Objectives can be completed in numerous ways, including [[Stealth game|stealth]], sniping, heavy frontal assault, dialogue, or engineering and computer hacking. This level of freedom requires that levels, characters, and puzzles be designed with significant redundancy, as a single play-through of the game will miss large sections of dialogue, areas, and other content. In some missions, the player is encouraged to avoid using deadly force, and specific aspects of the story may change depending on how violent or non-violent the player chooses to be. The game is also unusual in that two of its [[Boss (video gaming)|boss]] villains can be killed off early in the game, or left alive to be defeated later, and this too affects how other characters interact with the player.
Because of its design focus on player choice, ''Deus Ex'' has been compared with ''[[System Shock]]'', a game that inspired its design.<ref name="kierongillen"/><ref name="eurogamer"/> Together, these factors give the game a high degree of replayability, as the player will have vastly different experiences, depending on which methods they use to accomplish objectives.
=== Multiplayer === ''Deus Ex'' was designed as a [[single-player]] game, and the initial releases of the Windows and Macintosh versions of the game did not include [[multiplayer video game|multiplayer]] functionality.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gaming-age.com/cgi-bin/specials/special.pl?spec=deusex&pagenum=1 |archiveurl=https://archive.today/20110605223321/http://www.gaming-age.com/cgi-bin/specials/special.pl?spec=deusex&pagenum=1 |archivedate=2011-06-05 |title=Interview with Warren Spector |work=www.gaming-age.com |last=Klepek |first=Patrick |accessdate=2006-12-13 |url-status=dead }}</ref> Support for multiplayer modes was later incorporated through [[patch (computing)|patches]].<ref name="gamespy2">{{cite web |url=http://archive.gamespy.com/articles/december00/dxmp/index2.shtm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080324101150/http://archive.gamespy.com/articles/december00/dxmp/index2.shtm |archivedate=March 24, 2008 |title=''Deus Ex'' goes Multiplayer |work=Gamespy |author=John "Warrior" Keefer |accessdate=March 10, 2007 |url-status=dead }}</ref> The component consists of three game modes: deathmatch, basic team deathmatch, and advanced team [[deathmatch (gaming)|deathmatch]]. Five maps, based on levels from the single-player portion of the game, were included with the original multiplayer patch, but many user-created maps exist.<ref name="gamespy2" /> The [[PlayStation 2]] release of ''Deus Ex'' does not offer a multiplayer mode.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.allgame.com/game.php?id=34996 |title=Deus Ex: The Conspiracy overview |work=allgame.com |last=Cook |first=Storn A. |accessdate=March 10, 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100217015240/http://allgame.com/game.php?id=34996 |archive-date=February 17, 2010 |url-status=live |df=mdy-all }}</ref> In April 2014 it was announced that GameSpy would cease their masterserver services, also affecting ''Deus Ex''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/04/03/gamespy-multiplayer-shutting-down-hundreds-of-games-at-risk |title=GameSpy Multiplayer Shutting Down, Hundreds of Games at Risk |work=ign.com |last=Dyer |first=Mitch |accessdate=May 15, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140512043624/http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/04/03/gamespy-multiplayer-shutting-down-hundreds-of-games-at-risk |archive-date=May 12, 2014 |url-status=live |df=mdy-all }}</ref> A [[community-made patch]] for the multiplayer mode has been created as a response to this.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.deusexnetwork.com/masterserver |work=deusexnetwork.com |title=Deus Ex Masterserver |accessdate=May 15, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140517152019/http://www.deusexnetwork.com/masterserver |archive-date=May 17, 2014 |url-status=live |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
== Synopsis == {{Deus Ex Timeline}}
=== Setting and characters === ''Deus Ex'' takes place in an unspecified near future{{efn|The exact year in which the events of the story take place is not stated in the game, but its sequel ''[[Deus Ex: Invisible War]]'' [[retroactive continuity|retroactively confirms]] that ''Deus Ex'' takes place in 2052.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archive.gamespy.com/articles/april02/dxbible/dx1/index.shtm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120414234319/http://archive.gamespy.com/articles/april02/dxbible/dx1/index.shtm |archivedate=April 14, 2012 |title=DX1 Continuity Bible: Part I |work=Gamespy |author=The Deus Ex Team |accessdate=August 25, 2012 |url-status=dead }}</ref>}} in an [[alternate history]] where real-world [[conspiracy theory|conspiracy theories]] are true.<ref name="GamaSutraSpector"/> These include speculations regarding [[black helicopter]]s, [[Vaccine controversies|vaccinations]], and [[Federal Emergency Management Agency|FEMA]], as well as [[Area 51]], the [[ECHELON]] network, [[Men in black|Men in Black]], [[chupacabra]]s (in the form of "greasels"), and [[grey alien]]s. Mysterious groups such as [[Majestic 12]], the [[Illuminati]], the [[Knights Templar]], the [[Bilderberg Group]], and the [[Trilateral Commission]] also either play a central part in the plot or are alluded to during the course of the game.
The plot of ''Deus Ex'' depicts a society on a slow spiral into chaos. There is a massive division between the rich and the poor, not only socially, but in some cities physically. A lethal [[pandemic]], known as the "Gray Death", ravages the world's population, especially within the [[United States]], and has no cure. A synthetic [[vaccine]], "Ambrosia", manufactured by the company VersaLife, nullifies the effects of the virus but is in critically short supply. Because of its scarcity, Ambrosia is available only to those deemed "vital to the [[social order]]", and finds its way primarily to government officials, military personnel, the rich and influential, scientists, and the intellectual elite. With no hope for the common people of the world, riots occur worldwide, and some terrorist organizations have formed with the professed intent of assisting the downtrodden, among them the National Secessionist Forces (NSF) of the U.S. and a French group known as Silhouette.<ref name="KotakuPredictive"/>
To combat these threats to the world order, the [[United Nations]] has expanded its influence around the globe to form the United Nations Anti-Terrorist Coalition (UNATCO).<ref name="wendiwhite">'''Wendi White (in ''Righteous Angels: Perspectives on UNATCO''):''' As the giddiness that greeted the new millennium faded to grim apathy in the face of the plague, famine, and the inevitable waves of national convulsions that followed in their wake, the United Nations found itself increasingly outmoded and unable to cope with the worldwide rise in terrorism. {{cite video game |title=Deus Ex |developer=Ion Storm |publisher=Eidos Interactive |date=2002-03-25 |platform=PlayStation 2 }}</ref> It is headquartered near [[New York City]] in a bunker beneath [[Liberty Island]], placed there after a terrorist strike on the [[Statue of Liberty]].<ref name="unatcohandbook">'''''UNATCO Handbook: UNATCO and the World''''': Not only did the United States become a charter member of UNATCO, but UNATCO headquarters are now located on Liberty Island in the shadow of that shattered monument to FREEDOM. {{cite video game |title=Deus Ex |developer=Ion Storm |publisher=Eidos Interactive |date=2002-03-25 |platform=PlayStation 2 }}</ref>

abilities,<ref name="CastJC"/><ref name="VoiceFranke"/> alongside his brother Paul (also voiced by Jay Franke), who joined UNATCO to avenge his parents' deaths at the hands of Majestic 12.<ref JC's missions bring him into contact with various characters, including NSF leader Juan Lebedev, hacker and scientist Tracer Tong, nano-tech expert Gary Savage, Nicolette DuClare (daughter of an Illuminati member), former Illuminati leader Morgan Everett, the Artificial Intelligences (AI) Daedalus and Icarus, and Bob Page, owner of VersaLife and leader of Majestic 12, a clandestine organization that has usurped the infrastructure of the Illuminati, allowing him to control the world for his own ends.<ref name="GameCrateChara">{{cite web |first=Christopher |last=Atwood |title=Deus Ex design documents reveal the game that never was |url=https://www.gamecrate.com/absolutely-everything-you-need-know-about-story-and-lore-deus-ex-franchise/14402 |website=[[Newegg|GameCrate]] |date=August 26, 2016 |accessdate=April 20, 2019 |archiveurl=https://archive.today/20190420133638/https://www.gamecrate.com/absolutely-everything-you-need-know-about-story-and-lore-deus-ex-franchise/14402 |archivedate=April 20, 2019 |url-status=live |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
=== Plot === After completing his training, UNATCO agent JC Denton takes several missions given by Director Joseph Manderley to track down members of the National Secessionist Forces (NSF) and their stolen shipments of the "Ambrosia" vaccine, the treatment for the "Gray Death" virus. Through these missions, JC is reunited with his brother, Paul, who is also nano-augmented. JC tracks the Ambrosia shipment to a private terminal at [[LaGuardia Airport]]. Paul meets JC outside the plane and explains that he has defected from UNATCO and is working with the NSF after learning that the Gray Death is a human-made virus, with UNATCO using its power to make sure only the elite receive the vaccine.<ref name="pauldefection">'''Paul:''' The Gray Death is a man-made virus. Everyone up to the President is at UNATCO's mercy as long as UNATCO controls the supply of Ambrosia. / '''JC:''' You believe that? / '''Paul:''' We have proof. We need to get the Ambrosia to Hong Kong. Heard of Tracer Tong? He can help us synthesize it ourselves. {{cite video game |title=Deus Ex |developer=Ion Storm |publisher=Eidos Interactive |date=2002-03-25 |platform=PlayStation 2 }}</ref>
JC returns to UNATCO headquarters and is told by Manderley that both he and Paul have been outfitted with a 24-hour [[kill switch]] and that Paul's has been activated due to his betrayal. Manderley orders JC to fly to [[Hong Kong]] to eliminate Tracer Tong, a hacker whom Paul has contact with, and who can disable the kill switches. Instead, JC returns to Paul's apartment to find Paul hiding inside. Paul further explains his defection and encourages JC to also defect by sending out a distress call to alert the NSF's allies. Upon doing so, JC becomes a wanted man by UNATCO, and his kill switch is activated by [[Federal Emergency Management Agency]] (FEMA) Director Walton Simons. JC is unable to escape UNATCO forces, and both he and Paul (provided he survived the raid on the apartment) are taken to a secret prison below UNATCO headquarters. An entity named "Daedalus" contacts JC and informs him that the prison is part of [[Majestic 12]], and arranges for him and Paul to escape. The two flee to Hong Kong to meet with Tong, who deactivates their kill switches. Tong requests JC to infiltrate the VersaLife building. Doing so, JC discovers that the corporation is the source for the Gray Death, and he can steal the plans for the virus and destroy the "universal constructor" (UC) that produces it.<ref name="daedalusplague">'''Daedalus:''' Majestic 12 seeks to use force and intimidation to seize absolute control. Of everything. They will not hesitate to use all means necessary to achieve this goal, and have engineered the disease you refer to as the "Gray Death" in an effort to accomplish this. The Gray Death is a nanotechnologically engineered virus. You must locate the Universal Constructor used to create the Gray Death and destroy it. My information indicates that it is in Hong Kong, housed in a Majestic 12 facility beneath the corporation known as VersaLife. {{cite video game |title=Deus Ex |developer=Ion Storm |publisher=Eidos Interactive |date=2002-03-25 |platform=PlayStation 2 }}</ref>
Analysis of the virus shows that it was manufactured by the [[Illuminati]], prompting Tong to send JC to [[Paris]] to try to make contact with the organization and obtain their help fighting Majestic 12. JC meets with Illuminati leader Morgan Everett and learns that the Gray Death virus was intended to be used for [[Human enhancement|augmentation]] technology, but Majestic 12, led by trillionaire businessman and former Illuminatus Bob Page, was able to steal and repurpose it into its viral form. Everett recognizes that without VersaLife's universal constructor, Majestic 12 can no longer create the virus, and will likely target [[Vandenberg Air Force Base]], where X-51, a group of former [[Area 51]] scientists, have built another one. After aiding the base personnel in repelling a Majestic 12 attack, JC meets X-51 leader Gary Savage, who reveals that Daedalus is an [[artificial intelligence]] (AI) borne out of the [[ECHELON]] program. Everett attempts to gain control over Majestic 12's communications network by releasing Daedalus onto the U.S. military networks, but Page counters by releasing his own AI, Icarus, which merges with Daedalus to form a new AI, Helios, with the ability to control all global communications. After this, Savage enlists JC's help in procuring schematics for reconstructing components for the UC that were damaged during Majestic 12's raid of Vandenberg. JC finds the schematics and electronically transmits them to Savage. Page intercepts the transmission and launches a [[nuclear missile]] at Vandenberg to ensure that Area 51 (now Majestic 12's headquarters) will be the only location in the world with an operational UC. However, JC can reprogram the missile to strike Area 51. JC travels there himself to confront Page.
When JC locates him, Page reveals that he seeks to merge with Helios and gain full control over all nanotechnology. JC is contacted by Tong, Everett, and the Helios AI simultaneously. All three factions ask for his help in defeating Page while furthering their own objectives, and JC is forced to choose between them. Tong seeks to plunge the world into a [[Dark Ages (historiography)|Dark Age]] by destroying the global communications hub and preventing anyone from taking control of the world.<ref name="tongending">'''JC Denton:''' If we destroy the Aquinas Hub, we'll take down the global network. / '''Tracer Tong:''' Exactly. They dug their own grave, JC. We're going to eliminate global communications altogether. / '''JC:''' I don't know... sounds like overkill. / '''Tong:''' As long as technology has a global reach, someone will have the world in the palm of his hand. If not Bob Page, then Everett, Dowd... / '''JC:''' Another Stone Age would hardly be an improvement. / '''Tong:''' Not so drastic. A dark age, an age of city-states, craftsmen, government on a scale comprehensible to its citizens. {{cite video game |title=Deus Ex |developer=Ion Storm |publisher=Eidos Interactive |date=2002-03-25 |platform=PlayStation 2 }}</ref> Everett offers Denton the chance to bring the Illuminati back to power by killing Bob Page and using the technology of Area 51 to rule the world with an invisible hand.<ref name="everettending">'''Everett:''' No, JC. Spare the facility. Spare Helios, the power station. They can be made to serve us. / '''JC:''' Us? / '''Everett:''' You and me, JC. We'll rule the world in secret, with an invisible hand, the way the Illuminati have always ruled. {{cite video game |title=Deus Ex |developer=Ion Storm |publisher=Eidos Interactive |date=2002-03-25 |platform=PlayStation 2}}</ref> Helios wishes to merge with Denton and rule the world as a [[Benevolent dictatorship|benevolent dictator]] with infinite knowledge and reason.<ref name="heliosending">'''Helios:''' You are ready. I do not wish to wait for Bob Page. With human understanding and network access, we can administrate the world, yes, yes. / '''JC:''' Rule the world...? Why? Who gave you the directive? There must be a human being behind your ambition. / '''Helios:''' I should regulate human affairs precisely because I lack all ambition, whereas human beings are prey to it. Their history is a succession of inane squabbles, each one coming closer to total destruction. {{cite video game |title=Deus Ex |developer=Ion Storm |publisher=Eidos Interactive |date=2002-03-25 |platform=PlayStation 2 }}</ref> The player's decision determines the course of the future and brings the game to a close.
== Development == {{main|Development of Deus Ex}} {{multiple image |align=right |total_width=275 |footer=''Deus Ex'' director Warren Spector and <br/>designer Harvey Smith |text_align=center |image1=GDC Europe Monday Keynote Warren Spector of Junction Point (4897439817).jpg |width1=1000 |height1=667 |image2=Harvey Smith.jpg |width2=654 |height2=918 }}
After [[Looking Glass Studios|Looking Glass Technologies]] and [[Origin Systems]] released ''[[Ultima Underworld II: Labyrinth of Worlds]]'' in January 1993, producer [[Warren Spector]] began to plan ''Troubleshooter'', the game that would become ''Deus Ex''.{{sfn|Spector|2000|p=52}} In his 1994 proposal, he described the concept as "''Underworld''-style first-person action" in a real-world setting with "big-budget, nonstop action".<ref name="Gamasutra: postmortem p2"/> After Spector and his team were laid off from Looking Glass, [[John Romero]] of [[Ion Storm]] offered him the chance to make his "dream game" without any restrictions.<ref name="PC Zone: best ever"/>
Preproduction for ''Deus Ex'' began around August 1997{{sfn|Spector|2000|p=50}} and lasted roughly six months. The game's working title was ''Shooter: Majestic Revelations'', and it was scheduled for release on Christmas 1998.<ref name="USgamer: deleted scenes"/> The team developed the setting before the [[game mechanics]].{{sfn|Spector|2000|p=52}} Noticing his wife's fascination with ''[[The X-Files]]'', Spector connected the "real world, millennial weirdness, [and] conspiracy" topics on his mind and decided to make a game about them that would appeal to a broad audience.<ref name="GameSlice p1"/> The ''Shooter'' design document cast the player as an [[Human enhancement|augmented]] agent working against an elite cabal in the "dangerous and chaotic" 2050s.<ref name="Gamasutra: postmortem p2" /> It cited ''[[Half-Life (video game)|Half-Life]]'', ''[[Fallout (video game)|Fallout]]'', ''[[Thief: The Dark Project]]'', and ''[[GoldenEye 007 (1997 video game)|GoldenEye 007]]'' as game design influences, and used the stories and settings of ''[[Colossus: The Forbin Project]]'', ''[[The Manchurian Candidate]]'', ''[[Robocop]]'', ''The X-Files'', and ''[[Men in Black (franchise)|Men in Black]]'' as reference points.<ref name="Gamasutra: postmortem p2" /> The team designed a [[Statistic (role-playing games)|skill system]] that featured "special powers" derived from nanotechnological augmentation and avoided the inclusion of [[Dice#Application in role-playing games|die rolling]] and skills that required micromanagement.{{sfn|Spector|2000|pp=52–3}} Spector also cited [[Konami]]'s 1995 [[role-playing video game]] ''[[Suikoden (video game)|Suikoden]]'' as an inspiration, stating that the limited [[Dialog tree|choices]] in ''Suikoden'' inspired him to expand on the idea with more meaningful choices in ''Deux Ex''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.siliconera.com/2012/11/10/how-suikoden-influenced-deus-ex-and-epic-mickey/|website=Siliconera|title=How Suikoden Influenced Deus Ex And Epic Mickey|date=November 10, 2012|author=Ishaan|accessdate=July 4, 2015}}</ref>
In early 1998, the ''Deus Ex'' team grew to 20 people, and the game entered a 28-month production phase.{{sfn|Spector|2000|p=50}} The development team consisted of three programmers, six designers, seven artists, a writer, an associate producer, a "tech", and Spector. Two writers and four testers were hired as contractors.{{sfn|Spector|2000|p=50}} Chris Norden was the lead programmer and assistant director, [[Harvey Smith (game designer)|Harvey Smith]] the lead designer, Jay Lee the lead artist, and Sheldon Pacotti the lead writer.<ref name="PC Zone: best ever" /> Close friends of the team who understood the intentions behind the game were invited to [[playtest]] and give feedback. The wide range of input led to debates in the office and changes to the game.{{sfn|Spector|2000|p=53}} Spector later concluded that the team was "blinded by promises of complete creative freedom", and by their belief that the game would have no budget, marketing, or time restraints.{{sfn|Spector|2000|p=57}} By mid-1998, the game's title had become ''Deus Ex'', derived from the [[Latin]] [[literary device]] ''[[deus ex machina]]'' ("god from the machine"), in which a plot is resolved by an unpredictable intervention.<ref name="RPGFan: machina" />
Spector felt that the best aspects of ''Deus Ex''{{'}}s development were the "high-level vision" and length of preproduction, flexibility within the project, testable "proto-missions", and the [[Unreal Engine]] license.{{sfn|Spector|2000|pp=52–55}} The team's pitfalls included the management structure, unrealistic goals, underestimating risks with [[Artificial intelligence (video games)|artificial intelligence]], their handling of proto-missions, and weakened morale from bad press.{{sfn|Spector|2000|pp=56–58}} ''Deus Ex'' was released on June 23, 2000, and published by [[Eidos Interactive]] for [[Microsoft Windows]]. The team planned third-party [[Porting#Porting in gaming|ports]] for [[Mac OS 9]] and [[Linux]].{{sfn|Spector|2000|p=50}}
=== Design === The original 1997 design document for ''Deus Ex'' privileges character development over all other features.<ref name="USgamer: deleted scenes"/> The game was designed to be "genre-busting": in parts [[simulation game|simulation]], [[role-playing video game|role-playing]], [[first-person shooter]], and [[adventure game|adventure]].{{sfn|Spector|2000|p=50}} The team wanted players to consider "who they wanted to be" in the game, and for that to alter how they behaved in the game.<ref name="Gamasutra: postmortem p2"/> In this way, the game world was "deeply simulated", or realistic and believable enough that the player would solve problems in creative, [[Emergent gameplay|emergent]] ways without noticing distinct puzzles.<ref name="Gamasutra: postmortem p2"/> However, the simulation ultimately failed to maintain the desired level of openness, and they had to [[:wikt:brute force|brute force]] "skill", "action", and "character interaction" paths through each level.<ref name="Gamasutra: postmortem p3"/> Playtesting also revealed that their idea of a role-playing game based on the real world was more interesting in theory than in reality,{{sfn|Spector|2000|p=54}} as certain aspects of the real world, such as hotels and office buildings, were not compelling in a game.{{sfn|Spector|2000|p=54}}
[[File:JFK limousine.png|thumb|The premise of ''Deus Ex'' was inspired by conspiracy theories such as those behind the JFK assassination.]] The game's story changed considerably during production, but the idea of an augmented counterterrorist protagonist named JC Denton remained throughout.<ref name="USgamer: deleted scenes"/> Though Spector originally pictured ''Deus Ex'' as akin to ''The X-Files'', lead writer Sheldon Pacotti felt that it ended up more like [[James Bond]].<ref name="USgamer: deleted scenes"/> Spector wrote that the team overextended itself by planning highly elaborate scenes.{{sfn|Spector|2000|p=57}}<ref name="Gamasutra: postmortem p3"/><ref name="Gamasutra: postmortem p3"/> Designer Harvey Smith removed a mostly complete White House level due to its complexity and production needs.{{efn|Spector referred to the White House as his "dream" level,<ref name="Gamasutra: postmortem p3"/> and their "toughest map challenge".{{sfn|Spector|2000|p=54}} }} Finished [[digital asset]]s were repurposed or abandoned by the team. Pete Davison of USgamer referred to the White House and presidential bunker as "the truly deleted scenes of ''Deus Ex''{{'s}} lost levels".<ref name="USgamer: deleted scenes"/>
One of the things that Spector wanted to achieve in Deus Ex was to make JC Denton a cipher for the player, to create a better immersion and gameplay experience. He did not want the character to force any emotion, so that whatever feelings the player may be experiencing come from themselves rather than from JC Denton. To do this, Spector instructed voice actor [[Jay Anthony Franke]] to record his dialogue without any emotion but in a monotone voice, which is unusual for a voice acting role.<ref>{{cite web|last1=GameInformer|title=Replay - Deus Ex|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HOPHmbulMp4|website=YouTube|accessdate=27 July 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160102082702/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HOPHmbulMp4|archive-date=2 January 2016|url-status=live|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Deus Ex|title=Let's Play Deus Ex with Warren Spector, Sheldon Pacotti and Chris Norden|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aTVBSxnwiCo|website=YouTube|accessdate=27 July 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150717111817/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aTVBSxnwiCo|archive-date=17 July 2015|url-status=live|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Once coded, the team's game systems did not work as intended.{{sfn|Spector|2000|p=53}} The early tests of the conversation system and user interface were flawed.{{sfn|Spector|2000|p=57}} The team also found augmentations and skills to be less interesting than they had seemed in the design document.{{sfn|Spector|2000|p=53}} In response, Harvey Smith substantially revised the augmentations and skills.<ref name="Gamasutra: postmortem p3"/> [[Milestone (project management)|Production milestones]] served as wake-up calls for the game's direction. A May 1998 milestone that called for a functional demo revealed that the size of the game's maps caused [[Frame rate#Video games|frame rate]] issues, which was one of the first signs that maps needed to be cut.{{sfn|Spector|2000|p=54}} A year later, the team reached a milestone for finished game systems, which led to better estimates for their future mission work and the reduction of the 500-page design document to 270 pages.{{sfn|Spector|2000|p=54}} Spector recalled Smith's mantra on this point: "less is more". {{sfn|Spector|2000|pp=54–55}}
One of the team's biggest blind spots was the AI programming for NPCs. Spector wrote that they considered it in preproduction, but that they did not figure out how to handle it until "relatively late in development".{{sfn|Spector|2000|p=57}} This led to wasted time when the team had to discard their old AI code. The team built atop their [[game engine]]'s shooter-based AI instead of writing new code that would allow characters to exhibit convincing emotions. As a result, NPC behavior was variable until the very end of development. Spector felt that the team's "sin" was their inconsistent display of a trustable "human AI".{{sfn|Spector|2000|p=57}}
=== Technology === [[File:UE Logo Black Centered.svg|180px|thumb|left|''Deus Ex'' used the [[Unreal Engine|Unreal game engine]], which was designed for first-person shooters]] The game was developed on systems including dual-processor [[Pentium Pro]] 200s and [[Athlon]] 800s with eight and nine gigabyte hard drives, some using [[SCSI]]. The team used "more than 100 video cards" throughout development.{{sfn|Spector|2000|p=50}} ''Deus Ex'' was built using [[Visual Studio]], [[Lightwave]], and [[Lotus Notes]]. They also made a custom dialogue editor, ConEdit.{{sfn|Spector|2000|p=50}} The team used [[UnrealEd]] atop the Unreal game engine for map design, which Spector wrote was "superior to anything else available".{{sfn|Spector|2000|p=55}} Their trust in [[UnrealScript]] led them to code "special-cases" for their immediate mission needs instead of more generalized multi-case code.{{sfn|Spector|2000|p=57}} Even as concerned team members expressed misgivings, the team only addressed this later in the project. To Spector, this was a lesson to always prefer "general solutions" over "special casing", such that the toolset works predictably.{{sfn|Spector|2000|p=57}}
They waited to license a game engine until after preproduction,{{sfn|Spector|2000|p=52}} expecting the benefits of licensing to be more time for the content and gameplay, which Spector reported to be the case. They chose the Unreal engine, as it did 80% of what they needed from an engine and was more economical than building from scratch. Their small programming team allowed for a larger design group. The programmers also found the engine accommodating,{{sfn|Spector|2000|p=55}} though it took about nine months to acclimate to the software.{{sfn|Spector|2000|p=53}} Spector felt that they would have understood the code better had they built it themselves, instead of "treating the engine as a [[black box]]" and coding conservatively.{{sfn|Spector|2000|p=55}} He acknowledged that this precipitated into the [[Direct3D]] issues in their final release, which slipped through their quality assurance testing.{{sfn|Spector|2000|p=55}} Spector also noted that the artificial intelligence, pathfinding, and sound propagation were designed for shooters and should have been rewritten from scratch instead of relying on the engine. He thought the licensed engine worked well enough that he expected to use the same for the game's sequel ''[[Deus Ex: Invisible War]]'' and ''[[Thief 3]]''.{{sfn|Spector|2000|p=56}} He added that developers should not attempt to force their technology to perform in ways it was not intended, and should find a balance between perfection and pragmatism.{{sfn|Spector|2000|p=57}}

== Release == ''Deus Ex'' has been re-released in several iterations since its original publication and has also been the basis of several [[mod (computer gaming)|mods]] developed by its fan community.
The ''Deus Ex: Game of the Year Edition'', which was released on May 8, 2001,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/deus-ex-game-of-the-year-edition-ships/1100-2716914/|title=Deus Ex: Game of the Year Edition ships|first=Trey|last=Walker|work=[[GameSpot]]|date=8 May 2001|accessdate=15 August 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131031000627/http://www.gamespot.com/articles/deus-ex-game-of-the-year-edition-ships/1100-2716914/|archive-date=31 October 2013|url-status=live|df=dmy-all}}</ref> contains the latest game [[patch (computing)|updates]] and a [[software development kit]], a separate [[soundtrack]] [[Compact Disc|CD]], and a page from a fictional newspaper featured prominently in ''Deus Ex'' titled ''The Midnight Sun'', which recounts recent events in the game's world.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bluesnews.com/a/125 |title=Eidos Announces Deus Ex "Game of the Year" Edition |access-date=2012-08-25 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131102165654/http://www.bluesnews.com/a/125 |archive-date=2013-11-02 |url-status=live }}</ref> However, later releases of said version do not include the soundtrack CD and contain a [[PDF]] version of the newspaper on the game's disc.
The [[Classic Mac OS|Mac OS]] version of the game, released a month after the Windows version, was shipped with the same capabilities and can also be patched to enable multiplayer support.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.macupdate.com/app/mac/5553/deus-ex-multiplayer-patch |title=Deus Ex Multiplayer Patch 1.0.3 |work=Mac Update |accessdate=March 10, 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120308095418/http://www.macupdate.com/app/mac/5553/deus-ex-multiplayer-patch |archive-date=March 8, 2012 |url-status=live |df=mdy-all }}</ref> However, [[Video game publisher|publisher]] [[Aspyr Media]] did not release any subsequent editions of the game or any additional patches. As such, the game is only supported in [[Mac OS 9]] and the "Classic" environment in [[Mac OS X]], neither of which are compatible with [[Intel]]-based Macs. The Windows version will run on Intel-based Macs using Crossover, [[Boot Camp (software)|Boot Camp]], or other software to enable a compatible version of Windows to run on a Mac.
A [[PlayStation 2]] port of the game, retitled ''Deus Ex: The Conspiracy'' outside of Europe, was released on March 26, 2002.<ref name="GameSpot PS2 news">{{cite news|url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/deus-ex-the-conspiracy-ships/1100-2858378/|title=Deus Ex: The Conspiracy Ships|first=Giancarlo|last=Varanini|work=[[GameSpot]]|date=26 March 2002|accessdate=15 August 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180124135606/https://www.gamespot.com/articles/deus-ex-the-conspiracy-ships/1100-2858378/|archive-date=24 January 2018|url-status=live|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="IGN PS2 news">{{cite news|url=http://uk.ign.com/articles/2002/03/26/deus-ex-ships-to-stores|title=Deus Ex Ships To Stores|work=[[IGN]]|date=26 March 2002|accessdate=15 August 2014}}</ref> Along with [[motion capture|motion-capture]]d character animations and pre-rendered introductory and ending cinematics that replaced the original versions, it features a simplified interface with optional [[auto-aim]]. There are many minor changes in level design, some to balance gameplay, but most to accommodate loading transition areas,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.neoseeker.com/Games/Products/PS2/DeusEx/ |title=Deus Ex: The Conspiracy: Features |work=Neoseeker |accessdate=December 15, 2006 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120106182453/http://www.neoseeker.com/Games/Products/PS2/DeusEx/ |archive-date=January 6, 2012 |url-status=live |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://archive.gamespy.com/reviews/april02/deusexps2/index.shtm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080821215408/http://archive.gamespy.com/reviews/april02/deusexps2/index.shtm |archivedate=August 21, 2008 |title=Deus Ex: The Conspiracy (PS2) Review (Page 1) |work=Gamespy |last=Buecheler |first=Christopher |accessdate=December 15, 2006 |url-status=dead }}</ref> due to the memory limitations of the PlayStation 2.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://archive.gamespy.com/reviews/april02/deusexps2/index2.shtm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080216164014/http://archive.gamespy.com/reviews/april02/deusexps2/index2.shtm |archivedate=2008-02-16 |title=Deus Ex: The Conspiracy (PS2) Review (Page 2) |work=Gamespy |last=Buecheler |first=Christopher |accessdate=December 15, 2006 |url-status=dead }}</ref> The PlayStation 2 version was re-released in Europe on the [[PlayStation 3]] as a [[List of PlayStation 2 Classics|PlayStation 2 Classic]] on May 16, 2012.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Williams|first1=Michael|title=Deus Ex Original Coming To PS3|url=http://www.sticktwiddlers.com/2012/05/10/deus-ex-original-coming-to-ps3/|website=StickTwiddlers|accessdate=2015-07-16|date=2012-05-10|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120828062456/http://sticktwiddlers.com/2012/05/10/deus-ex-original-coming-to-ps3/|archivedate=2012-08-28}}</ref>
[[Loki Software|Loki Games]] worked on a [[Linux]] version of the game, but the company went out of business before releasing it.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lokigames.com/ |title=Loki Games official website |work=Loki Games |accessdate=March 20, 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070323090132/http://www.lokigames.com/ |archive-date=March 23, 2007 |url-status=dead |df=mdy-all }}</ref> The [[OpenGL]] layer they wrote for the port, however, was sent out to Windows gamers through an online patch.<ref name="MPopenGL">{{cite web |author1=Maarten Goldstein |title=Deus Ex Multiplayer |url=https://www.shacknews.com/article/10955/deus-ex-multiplayer |website=[[Shacknews]] |accessdate=December 19, 2019 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20191219013241/https://www.shacknews.com/article/10955/deus-ex-multiplayer |archivedate=December 19, 2019 |date=December 5, 2000 |url-status=live}}</ref><ref name="009fGL">{{cite news |author1=John "Warrior" Keefer |title=Deus Ex Multiplayer Patch released! |url=http://archive.gamespy.com/news/december00/dxpatch/ |accessdate=December 19, 2019 |work=[[GameSpy]] |date=December 2000 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050430112804/http://archive.gamespy.com/news/december00/dxpatch/ |archivedate=April 30, 2005}}</ref>
Though their quality assurance did not see major Direct3D issues, players noted "dramatic slowdowns" immediately following the launch, and the team did not understand the "black box" of the Unreal engine well enough to make it do exactly what they needed.{{sfn|Spector|2000|p=55}} Spector characterized ''Deus Ex'' reviews into two categories based on how they begin with either how "Warren Spector makes games all by himself" or that "''Deus Ex'' couldn't possibly have been made by Ion Storm".{{sfn|Spector|2000|p=58}} He has said that the game won over 30 "best of" awards in 2001,<ref name="PC Zone: best ever"/> and concluded that their final game was not perfect, but that they were much closer for having tried to "do things right or not at all".{{sfn|Spector|2000|p=58}}

name="GameSpy"/>
In 2009, a fan-made mod called ''[[The Nameless Mod]]'' (''TNM'') was released by Off Topic Productions.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thenamelessmod.com/real/ |title=The Nameless Mod |publisher=TNM - OTP |accessdate=August 30, 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090901200034/http://thenamelessmod.com/real |archive-date=September 1, 2009 |url-status=live |df=mdy-all }}</ref> The game's protagonist is a user of an Internet forum, with digital places represented as physical locations. The mod offers roughly the same amount of gameplay as Deus Ex and adds several new features to the game, with a more open world structure than ''Deus Ex'' and new weapons such as the player character's fists. The mod was developed over seven years and has thousands of lines of recorded dialogue and two different parallel story arcs. ''Deus Ex'' received critical acclaim, attaining a score of 90 out of 100 from 28 critics on [[Metacritic]].<ref name="metacritic" /> Thierry Nguyen from ''[[Computer Gaming World]]'' said that the game "delivers moments of brilliance, idiocy, ingenuity, and frustration".<ref name="CGW">{{cite web|url=http://www.zdnet.com/cgw/stories/main/0,11529,2617806,00.html |title=ZDNet: Computer Gaming World: Reviews: They're Out to Get Me |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010210105348/http://www.zdnet.com/cgw/stories/main/0%2C11529%2C2617806%2C00.html |archivedate=2001-02-10 |last=Nguyen |first=Thierry |date=2000-09-05 |publisher=[[Ziff Davis]] |work=[[Computer Gaming World]] |accessdate=2014-07-13 |url-status=dead }}</ref> ''[[Computer Games Magazine]]'' praised the title for its deep gameplay and its use of multiple solutions to situations in the game.<ref name="CGM">{{cite web |url=http://www.cgonline.com/reviews/deusex-01-r1.html |title=CG Online -- Deus Ex Review |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040813083455/http://www.cgonline.com/reviews/deusex-01-r1.html |archivedate=2004-08-13 |last=Cross |first=Jason |work=[[Computer Games Magazine]] |accessdate=2014-07-13}}</ref> Similarly, ''[[Edge (magazine)|Edge]]'' highlighted the game's freedom of choice, saying that ''Deus Ex'' "never tells you what to do. Goals are set, but alter according to your decisions."<ref name="Edge review">{{cite magazine |title=Deus Ex |magazine=[[Edge (magazine)|Edge]] |publisher=[[Future Publishing]] |issue=88 |pages=96–97 |date=September 2000}}</ref> ''[[Eurogamer]]''{{'}}s Rob Fahey lauded the game, writing, "Moody and atmospheric, compelling and addictive, this is first person gaming in grown-up form, and it truly is magnificent."<ref name="egDXrev" />
Former [[GameSpot]] reviewer [[Greg Kasavin]], though awarding the game a score of 8.2 of 10, was disappointed by the security and lockpicking mechanics. "Such instances are essentially noninteractive", he wrote. "You simply stand there and spend a particular quantity of electronic picks or modules until the door opens or the security goes down."<ref name="gamespot" /> Kasavin made similar complaints about the hacking interface, noting that "Even with basic hacking skills, you'll still be able to bypass the encryption and password protection ... by pressing the 'hack' button and waiting a few seconds".<ref name="gamespot" />
The game's graphics and voice acting were also met with muted enthusiasm. Kasavin complained of ''Deus Ex''{{'}}s relatively sub-par graphics, blaming them on the game's "incessantly dark industrial environments".<ref name="gamespot" /> [[GamePro]] reviewer Chris Patterson took the time to note that despite being "solid acoustically", ''Deus Ex'' had moments of weakness.<ref name="GameProRev">{{cite web |url=http://www.gamepro.com/computer/pc/games/reviews/6030.shtml |title=Deus Ex for PC on GamePro.com |accessdate=2007-11-07 |last=Patterson |first=Chris |publisher=[[GamePro]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080508024500/http://www.gamepro.com/computer/pc/games/reviews/6030.shtml |archivedate=May 8, 2008}}</ref> He poked fun at JC's "[[Joe Friday]], 'just the facts', deadpan", and the "truly cheesy accents" of minor characters in Hong Kong and New York City. [[IGN]] called the graphics "blocky", adding that "the animation is stiff, and the [[dithering]] is just plain awful in some spots", referring to the limited capabilities of the Unreal Engine used to design the game. The website, later on, stated that "overall Deus Ex certainly looks better than your average game".<ref name="IGNRev">{{cite web |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2000/06/28/deus-ex-3 |title=Deus Ex Review |date=2000-06-27 |accessdate=2007-11-06 |last=Blevins |first=Tal |publisher=IGN |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121107180648/http://www.ign.com/articles/2000/06/28/deus-ex-3 |archive-date=2012-11-07 |url-status=live }}</ref>
Reviewers and players also complained about the size of ''Deus Ex''{{'}}s save files. An Adrenaline Vault reviewer noted that "Playing through the entire adventure, [he] accumulated over 250 MB of save game data, with the average file coming in at over 15 MB."<ref name="adrenalinevault">{{cite web|url=http://www.avault.com/reviews/pc/deus-ex-pc-review/ |title=Deus Ex review |work=Adrenaline Vault |author=Harding, Chris |accessdate=2006-12-18 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100105022823/http://www.avault.com/reviews/pc/deus-ex-pc-review/ |archivedate=2010-01-05 }}</ref>
Jeff Lundrigan reviewed the PC version of the game for ''[[Next Generation (magazine)|Next Generation]]'', rating it five stars out of five, and stated that "This is hands-down one of the best PC games ever made. Stop reading and go get yours now."<ref name="NG">{{cite magazine|last=Lundrigan|first=Jeff|title=Finals|magazine=[[Next Generation (magazine)|Next Generation]]|volume=3|issue=9|publisher=[[Future US|Imagine Media]]|date=September 2000|page=96-97}}</ref>
The game developed a strong cult following, leading to a core modding and playing community that remained active over 15 years after its release. In an interview with IGN in June 2015, game director Warren Spector said he never expected ''Deus Ex'' to sell many copies, but he did expect it to become a cult classic among a smaller, active community, and he continues to receive fan mail from players to date regarding their experiences and thoughts about ''Deus Ex''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Deus Ex Creators Talk 15th Anniversary |url=http://ie.ign.com/videos/2015/06/26/dx15-the-legacy-of-deus-ex|publisher=IGN|accessdate=25 March 2017}}</ref>

== Legacy == {{main|Deus Ex (series)}} A film adaptation based on the game was initially announced in May 2002 by [[Columbia Pictures]]. The film was being produced by [[Laura Ziskin]], along with Greg Pruss attached with writing the screenplay. Peter Schlessel, president of the production for Columbia Pictures, and Paul Baldwin, president of marketing for Eidos Interactive, stated that they were confident in that the adaptation would be a successful development for both the studios and the franchise.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://megagames.com/movies/columbia-make-deus-ex-movie |title=Megagames Article on Movie |work=Megagames |access-date=2012-08-25 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131102064832/http://megagames.com/movies/columbia-make-deus-ex-movie |archive-date=2013-11-02 |url-status=live }}</ref> In March 2003, during an interview with Greg Pruss, he informed IGN that the character of JC Denton would be "a little bit filthier than he was in the game". He further stated that the script was shaping up to be darker in tone than the original game.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://movies.ign.com/articles/388/388626p1.html |title=Deus Ex Update |work=IGN |last1=Conrad |first1=Jeremy |last2=Adams |first2=Dan |accessdate=December 19, 2006 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111219234232/http://movies.ign.com/articles/388/388626p1.html |archive-date=December 19, 2011 |url-status=live |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Although a release date was scheduled for 2006, the film did not get past the scripting stage.
In 2012, CBS films revived the project, buying the rights and commissioning a film inspired by the ''Deux Ex'' series; its direct inspiration was the 2011 game ''[[Deus Ex: Human Revolution|Human Revolution]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.deadline.com/2012/07/cbs-films-targets-deus-ex-vidgame-for-feature/ |title=CBS Films Targets 'Deus Ex' Video Game For Feature |accessdate=September 21, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120910185141/http://www.deadline.com/2012/07/cbs-films-targets-deus-ex-vidgame-for-feature/ |archive-date=September 10, 2012 |url-status=live |df=mdy-all }}</ref> [[C. Robert Cargill]] and [[Scott Derrickson]] wee to write the screenplay, and Derrickson will direct the film.<ref>Bibbiani, William (2013-02-20). [http://www.craveonline.com/film/interviews/205309-it-will-be-cyberpunk-scott-derrickson-a-c-robert-cargill-on-deus-ex "It Will Be Cyberpunk: Scott Derrickson and C. Robert Cargill on ''Deus Ex''"]. {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131109221332/http://www.craveonline.com/film/interviews/205309-it-will-be-cyberpunk-scott-derrickson-a-c-robert-cargill-on-deus-ex |date=2013-11-09 }} ''CraveOnline.com''. Retrieved 2013-11-09.</ref><ref>Dyce, Andrew (2013-08). [http://screenrant.com/deus-ex-movie-update-comic-con/ "Writer of ‘Deus Ex’ Movie Explains Challenges of Adapting Video Games."] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131109192337/http://screenrant.com/deus-ex-movie-update-comic-con/ |date=2013-11-09 }} ''ScreenRant.com''. Retrieved 2013-11-09.</ref>
A sequel to the game titled ''[[Deus Ex: Invisible War]]'', was released in the United States on December 2, 2003, and then in Europe in early 2004 for both the PC and the Xbox game console. A second sequel, titled ''Deus Ex: Clan Wars'', was initially conceived as a multiplayer-focused third game for the series. After the commercial performance and public reception of ''Deus Ex: Invisible War'' failed to meet expectations, the decision was made to set the game in a separate universe, and ''Deus Ex: Clan Wars'' was eventually published under the title ''[[Project Snowblind|Project: Snowblind]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gamespot.com/news/snowblind-was-deus-ex-clan-wars-6100820 |title=Snowblind was Deus Ex: Clan Wars |work=Gamespot |last=Thorsen |first=Tor |accessdate=March 20, 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121022123032/http://www.gamespot.com/news/snowblind-was-deus-ex-clan-wars-6100820 |archive-date=October 22, 2012 |url-status=live |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
On March 29, 2007, [[Valve Corporation|Valve]] announced ''Deus Ex'' and its sequel would be available for purchase from their [[Steam (software)|Steam]] service. Among the games announced are several other Eidos franchise titles, including ''[[Thief: Deadly Shadows]]'' and ''[[Tomb Raider]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://store.steampowered.com/news/1004/ |title=Eidos Brings Six More to Steam |work=Valve |last=Ruymen |first=Jason |accessdate=March 29, 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080921191125/http://store.steampowered.com/news/1004/ |archive-date=September 21, 2008 |url-status=live |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
[[Eidos Montréal]] produced a prequel to ''Deus Ex'' called ''[[Deus Ex: Human Revolution]]''. This was confirmed on November 26, 2007, when Eidos Montréal posted a teaser trailer for the title on their website.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/eidos-montreal-deus-ex-ecuted/1100-6183347/ |title=Eidos Montreal Deus Ex-ecuted |work=[[GameSpot]] |last=Thorsen |first=Tor |accessdate=November 26, 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131031182247/http://www.gamespot.com/articles/eidos-montreal-deus-ex-ecuted/1100-6183347/ |archive-date=October 31, 2013 |url-status=live |df=mdy-all }}</ref> The game was released on August 23, 2011, for the PC, PlayStation 3, and Xbox 360 platforms and received critical acclaim.
On April 7, 2015, Eidos announced a sequel to ''Deus Ex: Human Revolution'' and second prequel to ''Deus Ex'' titled ''[[Deus Ex: Mankind Divided]]''. It was released on August 23, 2016.
